description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 14, The Irish Government has agreed that there is "no truth" to conspiracy theories linking the spread of coronavirus with 5G. Liz Canavan Senior Official in the Department of the Taoiseach urged people to 'ignore misinformation' in a press briefing in Dublin.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: On July 20, a new report by the Department for Digital, Culture, Media, and Sport (DCMS) Select Committee has urged the Ireland Government to appoint an online harms regulator to hold online platforms to account. The report highlighted the spread of false claims online linking 5G to the virus, resulting in threats being made against telecoms engineers, as a clear sign of the dangers misinformation can pose.

description: On February 24, 2020, Ireland maintains Level Five of COVID-19 restrictions. Primary schools will re-open on Monday for the four young youngest ages groups, the equivalent of primaries one to four. Final year secondary students will also return then. Other pupils and students will resume their schooling in a phased manner over the coming weeks, along with preschool childcare.

description: On April 29, 2020, the Minister for Education and Skills Joe McHugh TD has announced a decision was taken following recommendations from an advisory group of stakeholders as part of planning for the State Examinations in response to the Covid-19 public health measures and the decision that the Junior Cycle State Examinations will not run this year. All third year Junior Cycle students to be awarded certificates for the completion of Junior Cycle by the Department of Education and Skills. Schools given autonomy to assess students and all students to receive a report on achievement. Adult learners to be given opportunity to take final Junior Cycle examinations in autumn.

description: The Minister for Education of Ireland has published “The Roadmap for the Full Return to School” on the 27th of July 2020. It sets out what the operation of schools will look like and the range of support available in a COVID-19 context. According to which the control Measures have been introduced to prevent the Introduction and Spread of COVID-19 in Schools. Measures included in the plan focuses on: 1. Know the Symptoms of COVID-19 2. Respiratory Hygiene 3. Hand Hygiene 4. Physical Distancing 5. Use of PPE in Schools (only recommended for teachers when 2 m.  distance is not an option).

description:
The Minister for Education of Ireland published “The Roadmap for the Full Return to School” on the 27th July 2020. "COVID-19 response plan for the safe reopening of primary schools: supports the sustainable reopening of the school where the overriding objective is to protect the health of staff and students while promoting the educational and development needs of the children in the school. 
Measures included in the plan focus on to be aware of the Symptoms of COVID-19 and Respiratory Hygiene, Hand Hygiene, Physical Distancing, Use of PPE in Schools (only recommended for teachers when 2 m.  distance is not an option)"

description: On 29 May 2020, the Government of Ireland introduced Roadmap to Reopening Society and Business that sets out Ireland's plan for lifting COVID-19 restrictions through five phases. The phased reopening of childcare services includes the following: Phase 3 (29 June), the opening of crèches, childminders, and pre-schools for children of essential workers in a phased manner with social distancing and other requirements applying. Phase 4 (20 July), the opening of crèches, childminders, and pre-schools for children of all other workers on a gradually increasing phased basis and slowly increasing thereafter.

description: On 7 August, 2020, the Minister for Education has announced an update to reopen schools fully at the end of the summer. All teachers in both primary and secondary schools, staff and students in secondary school are recommended to wear face coverings when a physical distance of two metres cannot be maintained. UPDATE: On August 21, 2020, the Minister for Education Norma Foley TD provided a further update regarding the plans to fully re-open schools. With some schools beginning to re-open next week (from September 1), the Minister acknowledged the enormous work being undertaken in school communities and the commitment of everyone involved in providing a safe environment for the return of children to the schools.

Pupils in special schools will attend on alternate days; Pupils in special classes in mainstream primary schools will attend every day. description: Ireland is enforcing the Closure and Regulations of school policy. Schools remain closed into February. While the Taoiseach previously said the government would review the restrictions on 31 January, a spokesperson confirmed yesterday that this would be done on 2 February. Government sources state that it is still their intention to get schools reopened in February. However, it is all very much dependent on the case numbers. it is currently planned with special schools reopening on 11 February, and classes in mainstream schools for pupils with special needs will resume on 22 February.

description: 24 June 2021, the Government of Ireland announced COVID-19 vaccines are now being rolled out in Ireland. The at-risk groups vaccinated against COVID-19 are people aged 65 and older who live in long-term care facilities (group 1)  frontline healthcare workers (group 2)  people aged 70 and older (group 3)  people aged 16 to 69 who are at very high risk (group 4)  people aged 65 to 69, including those at high risk (group 5 and 6)  people aged 16 to 64 who are at high risk (group 7)  pregnant women between 14 and 36 weeks  People aged 40 to 69 who have registered for their vaccine are also being vaccinated.      The COVID-19 vaccines currently approved for use in Ireland are the:    1) AstraZeneca vaccine (also known as 'Vaxzevria')  2) Moderna vaccine  3) Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine (also known as 'Comirnaty')  4) Janssen vaccine    A number of other vaccines are in the final stages of licensing and approval.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Regulatory approval process for administering the COVID-19 vaccine
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 19th October, the Minister for Health has announced several updates to Ireland’s COVID-19 Vaccination Programme: a booster dose of Comirnaty (Pfizer) vaccine be offered to all those aged 60 to 79 years who have completed their primary course with any COVID-19 vaccine; the booster dose should ideally be given six months (with a minimum interval of five months) following completion of the primary vaccination schedule. If a person in a group for whom a booster dose is recommended has had laboratory confirmed COVID-19 infection after a completed primary vaccine course (that is, a breakthrough infection), the booster dose should be delayed for at least six months after the COVID-19 infection was diagnosed.

description: On 21st February, the Minister for Health, announced new updates to Ireland’s COVID-19 vaccination programme. As recommended by NIAC, a booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine be offered to all children and young people aged 12-15 years. A booster dose of the mRNA vaccine Comirnaty should be given at an interval of six months or longer since completion of the primary vaccine series. For those children and young people aged 12 – 15 years who have experienced a breakthrough infection, the booster dose should be deferred for at least six months following the onset of infection.

description: On October 13, 2020, the new EU Recommendation on coordinating travel within the EU / EEA was adopted. From October 23, the Ireland Government has implemented the new EU ‘traffic lights’ approach to travel. This approach provides for regions across the European Union (EU) and European Economic Area (EEA) to be categorised as green, orange, red or grey, on the basis of the risk levels associated with COVID-19. Citizens who are considering any overseas travel are advised to carefully monitor the official advice and information from the public authorities in their destination. Currently, all passengers entering Ireland from red, orange and grey regions are requested to restrict their movements for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: One or more regional groupings

description: On December 30, 2020, the Irish government announced that travelers from EU-designated areas of low COVID-19 activity (so-called "green" regions) are not required to self-isolate; travelers from areas of medium or high COVID-19 activity (amber and red regions respectively) must self-isolate for 14 days; such persons may shorten their quarantine periods if they test negative after five days. Person arriving from "amber regions" need not self-isolate if they are able to produce proof of having tested negative for COVID-19 using a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken within the three days prior to travel. Freight transport workers, maritime employees, aircraft pilots, and individuals traveling for imperative business or family reasons are exempt from these measures. All arrivals must fill out a passenger locator form indicating the address where they will be staying.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On 27th July, the Ireland Health Department has announced that the online Passenger Locator Form will be upgraded to complement the travel measures introduced from 19 July. In particular, the enhanced Passenger Locator Form will support the implementation of the EU Digital COVID Certificate. The lifting of restrictions on non-essential travel allows certain passengers to travel without the requirement to quarantine or provide further tests based on their vaccination, recovery or RT-PCR test status. The changes to the Passenger Locator Form includes: a new visual layout has been developed for the online form to streamline the user experience; a one-time passcode is sent to the phone number given at the beginning of the process via SMS to verify the number. The passenger must enter this code to proceed with completing the form; a declaration of what documentation / proof of a medical event (vaccination, recovery or RT-PCR test result) the passenger holds; categories of passengers which are exempt from testing or quarantine restrictions can declare their exemption; new fields to capture the data (name, age, proof of medical event) of each child (under 18) which to be listed on the accompanying responsible adult’s form.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Ireland department of health announces the EU Digital COVID Certificates for booster vaccines are being issued on 13 January 2022. UPDATE: The original policy announced the EU Digital Covid Certificate is coming into effect. There is an update in detail.
COVID-19 vaccine certificates for the primary vaccination series will not be accepted for travel if more than 270 days (approx. 9 months) have passed since the final dose in the primary vaccine series. Vaccine certificates based on booster/additional doses are not time limited.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On November 3, in part of the public health response to COVID-19, the Ireland Health Service Executive (HSE) has announced a new video-based mental wellbeing programme called Minding Your Wellbeing is now freely accessible. The programme consists of 5 video sessions (of about 20 minutes each):
1.  Practicing Self-Care
2.  Understanding Our Thoughts
3.  Exploring Emotions
4.  Building Positive Relationships
5.  Improving Our Resilience

description:
On August 7, 2020, the Irish government implemented new internal border restrictions. Residents of Kildare, Offaly and Laois can only travel within their own county, other than for the following reasons:
To travel to and from work where that work cannot be done from home; To attend medical appointments, collect medicines and other health products; For vital family reasons, like providing care to children, elderly or vulnerable people, but excluding social family visits; For farming purposes, food production or care of animals. People are asked not to travel into any of these counties, other than for the reasons above, and you need to travel through these counties to get somewhere else. People are asked not stop in Kildare, Laois or Offaly during a journey unless for essential purposes.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: According to the decision of the Ireland government, starting from midnight of 21 October 2020, entire Ireland moves to Level 5. Those aged over 70 and the medically vulnerable are advised to continue to exercise personal judgement. It is recommended that they stay at home as much as possible, and limit engagement to a very small network for short periods of time while remaining physically distanced. description: From 22nd July 2020, the Republic of Ireland has released a "green list" of 15 countries, excluding Great Britain and the US, that travelers can go to and not self-isolate on their return.  The 15 countries are Malta, Finland, Norway, Italy, Hungary, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Cyprus, Slovakia, Greece, Greenland, Gibraltar, Monaco, and San Marino.

description: On 21 August 2020, Irish Government announced new restrictions on arrivals from abroad, including the requirement to quarantine on entry. Travelers entering Ireland from the following countries in the 'Green List' are exempt from self-isolating for 14 days:   Estonia  Finland  Greece  Greenland  Hungary  Italy  Latvia  Lithuania  Norway  Slovakia.

description:
On September 17, 2020, Ireland added Greece and Italy to the list of countries from which travelers are required to quarantine for 14 days on arrival, under new tighter travel restrictions to curb the spread of COVID-19. 
A new “Green List” allows travelers arriving from just seven countries to avoid the quarantine: Cyprus, Finland, Germany, Iceland, Latvia, Lithuania and Poland. (Reporting by Conor Humphries; Editing by Hugh Lawson)

description: On November 9, Ireland implemented the EU-wide “traffic light” system to regularize travel within the EU/international travel between member states. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control publishes a weekly map that assigns countries a red, orange, grey (denoting no information), or green rating based on an agreed set of criteria including COVID-19 infection rates.  International arrivals from red, orange, grey, and non-EU countries (with limited exceptions) are advised to self-isolate for 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From the 31st of December, 2020, the Irish government tightened international entry restrictions. Travelers from EU-designated areas of low COVID-19 activity (so-called "green" regions) are not required to self-isolate. Travelers from areas of medium or high COVID-19 activity (amber and red regions respectively) must self-isolate for 14 days; such persons may shorten their quarantine periods if they test negative after five days. Person arriving from "amber regions" need not self-isolate if they are able to produce proof of having tested negative for COVID-19 using a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test taken within the three days prior to travel. Freight transport workers, maritime employees, aircraft pilots, and individuals traveling for imperative business or family reasons are exempt from these measures. All arrivals must fill out a passenger locator form indicating the address where they will be staying.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 26th of January, 2021, the Irish government agreed that the current public health restrictions with additional measures will remain in place until 5 March 2021. Under these restrictions, passengers who arrive in breach of the pre-departure negative/'not detected' PCR requirement are required to undergo mandatory quarantine at a designated facility. Mandatory quarantine at a designated facility will be required for persons who arrive from Brazil and South Africa. In other cases, passengers will be required by law to quarantine at home
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On the 26th of February, 2021, Authorities in Ireland tightened international entry restrictions introduced to combat the spread of COVID-19 by adding further countries to the list of high risk or "Category 2" countries. Individuals arriving from these countries must observe a complete 14-day self-isolation period.Category 2 countries include Angola, Argentina, Austria, Bolivia, Botswana, Brazil, Burundi, Cape Verde, Chile, Colombia, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Lesotho, Malawi, Eswatini, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, South Africa, Suriname, Rwanda, Seychelles, Tanzania, UAE, Uruguay, Venezuela, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. Health officials are currently passing legislation to require arrivals from these countries to carry out their isolation in specifically designated hotels, though it is not confirmed when this measure will come into effect.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Ireland "announced new restrictions regarding the closures of non-essential retail businesses and facilities effective from midnight.

They include all theatres, clubs, gyms, hairdressers, betting offices, markets, and libraries. Hotels are to limit occupancy.

All non-essential retail outlets are to close to the public and all others are to implement physical distancing.

Cafes and restaurants should limit themselves to takeaway and delivery only. All sports events are cancelled.

description: On October 19, the Ireland Government has announced that the country will move to Level 5 Covid-19 restrictions from midnight October 21 until December 1. Wet pubs, bars, cafes and restaurants (including hotel restaurants and bars) take away food or delivery only. Wet pubs in Dublin remain closed. Nightclubs, discos and casinos will remain closed. description: On October 19, the Ireland Government has announced that the country will move to Level 5 Covid-19 restrictions from midnight October 21 until December 1. Wet pubs, bars, cafes and restaurants (including hotel restaurants and bars) take away food or delivery only. Wet pubs in Dublin remain closed. Nightclubs, discos and casinos will remain closed. People should work from home unless they are providing an essential service. Essential retail and essential services will remain open. This includes food shopping. All other retail and personal services are closed. Hotels, guesthouses and B&Bs may remain open, but only to support provision of essential services.

description: Irish authorities announced that all retail outlets, hairdressers, museums, and libraries will reopen from Tuesday, December 1, 2020, amid an easing of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) restrictions in the run-up to Christmas. description: On November 27, the Ireland Government announced that from December 4, restaurants and pubs operating as restaurants (serving a substantial meal) can open for indoor dining with additional restrictions, including a requirement for meals to be prepared on site, inside the premises, with a maximum of 6 people per table. All retail shops and shopping centres can open. All services such as hairdressers, beauticians, barbers and opticians can open with strict adherence to sectoral guidance on protective measures. Hotels, guesthouses and B&B's can open, but with services limited to residents. UPDATE: The Ireland Government announced that previous measures in place until 24 December from December 4.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On December 22, the Ireland Government announced that from midnight on December 24 until January 12, non-essential retail may remain open. The retail sector will be requested to defer January sales events. Gyms, leisure centres and swimming pools may remain open for individual training only. From 3pm December 24 until 12 January, restaurants and pubs operating as restaurants will close. Hotels, guesthouses and B&Bs are open for those with essential non-social and non-tourist purposes. Nightclubs, discos, and casinos remain closed. Public transport capacity should be restricted at 25%. People should continue to work from home unless essential for work which is an essential health, social care or other essential service and cannot be done from home.

description: On January 6, 2021, the Ireland Government announced that all retail is closed except for essential retail. Face coverings must be worn at retail and services. All non-essential services are closed. Click and collect from non-essential retail outlets should be discontinued with immediate effect. Existing orders may be collected. Hotels and accommodation open only for essential non-social and non-tourist purposes. Bars, cafes and restaurants (including hotel restaurants and bars) will take away food and delivery only. Wet pubs, nightclubs, discos and casinos will remain closed. Work from home unless essential for work, which is an essential health, social care or other essential service and cannot be done from home. Those measures will apply until the next order.

description: On March 24, 2020, the Ireland Government announced that all theatres, clubs, gyms/leisure centres, libraries and other similar outlets are to shut. All playgrounds and holiday/caravan parks will close. All places of worship are to restrict numbers entering at any one time to ensure adequate physical distancing. There will be an increased presence of park rangers and Gardaí in parks and public places to ensure physical distancing is being observed. The new powers afforded to the Gardaí will be used sparingly and only when necessary. These measures will take effect from tonight and remain in place until 19 April, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On June 19, 2020, the Ireland Government announced Phase 3; social visits to people’s homes should be limited to a maximum of 10 visitors – from no more than 4 other households. Indoor gatherings of up to 50 people when conducted in line with public health advice are permissible. Outdoor gatherings of up to 200 people, when conducted in line with public health advice, are permissible. UPDATE: On August 18, 2020, the Ireland Government announced new measures are being put in place across the country until 13 September; visitors to your home or garden should be limited to not more than 6 from not more than 3 households, all outdoor events are to be limited to 15 people, down from 200. Indoor events will be reduced from 50 people to just 6 people, except for businesses such as shops and restaurants.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Irish authorities imposed tighter restrictions in Dublin on Saturday, September 19, 2020, following an increase in coronavirus disease (COVID-19) cases in the city. Restrictions levels have been increased to Level 3 (third on a five-tier scale), meaning that gatherings of more than 15 people are banned, although weddings and funerals may go ahead with up to 25 guests from Monday. Visits to private homes may take place but are limited to one other household with no more than 6 people involved.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Irish government has decided today that, from midnight tomorrow (Thursday, 15th October 2020), the counties of Cavan, Donegal and Monaghan will be placed on Level 4 under the Plan for Living with COVID-19. According to this no visitors to the home or garden is allowed, with the exception of visits for essential purposes. In outdoor settings away from home/garden, up to 6 people from no more than 2 households can meet while maintaining strict social distancing – including for outdoor exercise and dining. And the existing exemption which allows for Club Championship games to be played behind closed doors has been removed.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 19, the Ireland Government has announced that the country will move to Level 5 Covid-19 restrictions from midnight October 21 until December 1. There should be no other visits to homes or gardens. It is possible to meet with 1 other household in an outdoor setting which is not a home or garden, such as a park, including for exercise. No other social or family gatherings should take place. Up to 25 guests can attend a wedding ceremony and reception, whether indoors or outdoors. Up to 25 mourners can attend to the funerals.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On November 27, the Ireland Government announced that from December 1 until December 18 people should not mix with any other households outside of those within their support bubble. In outdoor settings away from their home or garden, up to 6 people from a maximum of 2 households can meet, weddings can go ahead, but with a limit of 25 guests for ceremony and reception (irrespective of venue). No organised indoor gatherings should take place, organised outdoor gatherings of up to 15 people can take place. Non contact training only in pods of up to 15. No matches or other sporting events should take place, with some exceptions. Places of worship can open for services with a maximum of 50 people, up to 25 mourners can attend funerals.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On November 27, the Ireland Government announced that from December 18 people can mix with a maximum of 2 other households. In outdoor settings away from your home or garden, a maximum of 3 households can meet while maintaining strict physical distancing, weddings can go ahead, but with a limit of 25 guests for ceremony and reception (irrespective of venue). No organised indoor gatherings should take place, organised outdoor gatherings of up to 15 people can take place. Non contact training only in pods of up to 15. No matches or other sporting events should take place, with some exceptions. Places of worship can open for services with a maximum of 50 people, up to 25 mourners can attend funerals. UPDATE: The Ireland Government announced that previous measures in place until 24 December from December 4.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On May 1 2021, Irish Government announced the summer reopening roadmap, with some major changes expected in May. According to this, starting from June 17 2021, a maximum of 3 households or 6 people from any number of households can visit a private garden. Also, outdoor gatherings of 15 people and outdoor training of 15 people are permitted. A maximum of 50 mourners at funeral services are permitted. No other events are to take place. And a maximum of 50 guests at wedding services. Maximum 6 guests at indoor reception or 15 outdoors

description: From Thursday 5 August, 2021, the maximum number of guests permitted to attend a wedding will increase from 50 to 100 (current protective measures apply).   Theatres and cinemas - Up to 50 patrons permitted, with protective measures in place.  for outdoor events/venues a maximum of 200 attendees can attend the majority of venues. A limit of 500 people is in place for venues with capacity greater than 5,000 with appropriate protective measures in place - including social distancing requirements.    The number of mourners permitted at funeral services is 50 people, regardless of size of venue. description: On June 25, 2020, the Ireland Government announced that museums, galleries, theatres, concert halls and other cultural outlets, cinemas, music venues (excluding nightclubs and discos), leisure facilities, bingo halls, arcades, skating rinks, amusements parks, religious buildings and places of worship, caravan parks and holiday parks may reopen from 29 June 2020. UPDATE: On June 28, 2020, as part of the Ireland Government’s Roadmap for Reopening Society and Business, The National Museum of Ireland, Crawford Art Gallery Cork, Chester Beatty, National Library of Ireland, National Archives, National Gallery of Ireland are reopening either fully or partly to the public on 29 June, Irish Museum of Modern Art will reopen on 30 June.

description: On June 5, 2020, the Ireland Government announced that Phase 2 will put in place from June 8, 2020. Public transport capacity is limited because of social distancing requirements. Social distancing means that overall capacity remains extremely restricted. Groups of up to 15, including trainers and coaches, may return to non-contact outdoor training activity (but not matches) while maintaining social distancing at all times. It is recommended that face coverings be worn in public places, such as shops, and on public transport. UPDATE: On June 19, 2020, the Ireland Government announced Phase 3 instead of Phase 2. These measures will remain in place from 29 June until 20 July.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 19, 2020, the Ireland Government announced Phase 3 will remain in place from 29 June until 20 July. Social/family visits and gatherings are to allow for physical distancing of 2 metres and for adequate ventilation if they are taking place indoors. Meeting people outdoors is safer than meeting indoors. Physical distancing should be observed at all times when meeting others. Social distancing means that overall capacity remains restricted. Use public transport only for essential journeys. Face coverings must be worn. UPDATE: On July 15, 2020, the Irish government delays Phase 4 of Roadmap from July 20 to August 10.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: The Minister for Education of Ireland has published “The Roadmap for the Full Return to School” on the 27th of July 2020. It sets out what the operation of schools will look like and the range of support available in a COVID-19 context. According to which the control Measures have been introduced to prevent the Introduction and Spread of COVID-19 in Schools. Measures included in the plan focuses on: 1. Know the Symptoms of COVID-19 2. Respiratory Hygiene 3. Hand Hygiene 4. Physical Distancing 5. Use of PPE in Schools (only recommended for teachers when 2 m.  distance is not an option).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On 24 July, 2020, the Ireland Government announced that all schools will fully reopen in August. A comprehensive plan was brought to Cabinet detailing a package of measures and resources, which was subsequently published online. UPDATE: On 7 August, 2020, the Minister for Education has announced an update to reopen schools fully at the end of the summer. All teachers in both primary and secondary schools, staff and students in secondary school are recommended to wear face coverings when a physical distance of two metres cannot be maintained.

description: On 7 August, 2020, the Minister for Education has announced an update to reopen schools fully at the end of the summer. All teachers in both primary and secondary schools, staff and students in secondary school are recommended to wear face coverings when a physical distance of two metres cannot be maintained. UPDATE: On August 21, 2020, the Minister for Education Norma Foley TD provided a further update regarding the plans to fully re-open schools. With some schools beginning to re-open next week (from September 1), the Minister acknowledged the enormous work being undertaken in school communities and the commitment of everyone involved in providing a safe environment for the return of children to the schools.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 25, 2020, the Ireland Government announced that museums, galleries, theatres, concert halls and other cultural outlets, cinemas, music venues (excluding nightclubs and discos), leisure facilities, bingo halls, arcades, skating rinks, amusements parks, religious buildings and places of worship, caravan parks and holiday parks may reopen from 29 June 2020. UPDATE: On September 15, 2020, the Ireland Government announced that museums, galleries and other cultural attractions are open with protective measures in place (for example: a maximum capacity to allow 2 metres social distancing, one-way traffic withing the venue).

description: On 7 August, the Minister for Education has announced an update to reopen schools fully at the end of the summer. All teachers in both primary and secondary schools, staff and students in secondary school are recommended to wear face coverings when a physical distance of two metres cannot be maintained. UPDATE: On November 27, the Ireland Government announced that schools and creches are open with protective measures. Further, higher and adult education should remain primarily online.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On November 27, the Ireland Government announced that from December 4, restaurants and pubs operating as restaurants (serving a substantial meal) can open for indoor dining with additional restrictions, including a requirement for meals to be prepared on site, inside the premises, with a maximum of 6 people per table. All retail shops and shopping centres can open. All services such as hairdressers, beauticians, barbers and opticians can open with strict adherence to sectoral guidance on protective measures. Hotels, guesthouses and B&B's can open, but with services limited to residents. UPDATE: The Ireland Government announced that previous measures in place until 24 December from December 4.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Personal Grooming Businesses (e.g. hair salons)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

UPDATE: On December 30, the Ireland Minister for Education Norma Foley TD and Minister of State for Special Education and Inclusion Josepha Madigan TD have announced that the school Christmas break will be extended by three days, with schools reopening on Monday 11 January.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks inside Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On January 6, 2021, the Ireland Government announced that all retail is closed except for essential retail. Face coverings must be worn at retail and services. All non-essential services are closed. Click and collect from non-essential retail outlets should be discontinued with immediate effect. Existing orders may be collected. Hotels and accommodation open only for essential non-social and non-tourist purposes. Bars, cafes and restaurants (including hotel restaurants and bars) will take away food and delivery only. Wet pubs, nightclubs, discos and casinos will remain closed. Work from home unless essential for work, which is an essential health, social care or other essential service and cannot be done from home. Those measures will apply until the next order.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On January 6, 2021, the Ireland Government announced that special education (special schools and special classes) and specialised settings (such as Oberstown and high support special care schools and youth encounter projects) which will continue fully open from 11 January. All final year Leaving Certificate students, including Leaving Cert Applied, Leaving Cert Vocational Programme and the traditional Leaving Cert, can attend school for 3 days a week commencing from the week beginning 11 January. Higher, further and adult education should remain primarily online.

description: On January 6, 2021, the Ireland Government announced that special education (special schools and special classes) and specialised settings (such as Oberstown and high support special care schools and youth encounter projects) which will continue fully open from 11 January. All final year Leaving Certificate students, including Leaving Cert Applied, Leaving Cert Vocational Programme and the traditional Leaving Cert, can attend school for 3 days a week commencing from the week beginning 11 January. Higher, further and adult education should remain primarily online. UPDATE: On January 25, 2021, the Ireland Government announced that schools are currently closed for all students with remote learning in place. A phased return to in-person learning for children in special schools and children in special classes in mainstream schools will commence from 11 February.

description:
On 14 January 2022, the Ireland government announced 
a person who is a close contact, aged 13 years and older who has not  had a primary course of COVID-19 vaccine should use a well-fitted medical grade or FFP2 face mask for 10 days and restrict their movements for 7 days. They should also take regular antigen tests over 7 days, with the last test on day 7 and should fully adhere to protective measures

description:
Ireland's government announced for all people, who have symptoms of covid-19, no test is required but self-isolate until 48 hours after symptoms resolve.

Except people who are aged 55 years and older AND unboosted, have a high-risk medical condition, are immunocompromised, live in the same household as a person who is immunocompromised, provide care or support for person they know to be immunocompromised or pregnant should self isolate and get a PCR test. Follow public health advice on test results if having symptoms of COVID-19 on Feb.22.2022.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
